title: Water efficiency programs bankrolling private dams
text:
So-called "supplementary water", which cannot be captured by river operators and is surplus to consumption needs, are also held in the dams despite its importance to down-stream river uses.

The impact could leave the Murrumbidgee River disconnected from the Murray in most years, further hurting river users dealing with dry conditions and a lack of water coming down the Darling River.

If any other industry wasted taxpayer money on environmentally and socially damaging projects like this, there would be a national outcry. — Maryanne Slattery, report author

Report author Maryanne Slattery, a former Murray-Darling Basin Authority official, said the Coalition and Labor were incorrect in claiming no new dams have been built since the 2013 election.

"The reason politicians won't talk about these dams is that they do nothing for drought-stricken communities, the health of the river or struggling farmers," Ms Slattery said.

"If any other industry wasted taxpayer money on environmentally and socially damaging projects like this, there would be a national outcry."

Greens water spokeswoman Sarah Hanson-Young said corporate irrigators were ripping off the taxpayer and vulnerable river systems.

“It’s outrageous private dams that stop water flowing to downstream users and the environment are being built with public money for the exclusive use of big business, and yet no public information on these dams exists.

Advertisement

“There should an urgent audit of water licences and storages, both public and private. We also need a royal commission into the Murray-Darling Basin to get to the bottom of this mismanagement.

“Dams are not the answer and they are definitely not a drought policy. If the federal government really wants to help farmers and ensure the sustainability of our food bowl, they’ll start by getting a climate policy and cleaning up the mess they’ve made in the Murray-Darling Basin.”

Mr Littleproud held meetings with crop producers in the northern Victorian city of Mildura on Tuesday and said the report was without foundation.

"The dams are part of efficiency programmes," he said.

"The water saved by those efficiency programmes is now held by the Commonwealth as water for the benefit of the environment.

"These programmes are audited by the Commonwealth. The Murray-Darling Basin Authority checks annually whether water take limits are met annually and the reality is farmers are not taking more than they are entitled to."

Mr Littleproud said 95 per cent of recipients from the on-farm irrigation efficiency program received less than $1 million in total value.

"The department depends on independent technical advise on how much water is saved," he said.
description: Water Resources Minister David Littleproud says a new report on privately-owned dams winning taxpayer funding is without foundation.
